{{Infobox non-profit | name = SoundExchange | image = SoundExchange logo.png | caption = | founder = | type = [[Non-profit]] | tax_id = 760742496 | registration_id = | founded_date = September 22, 2003 | location = [[Washington, DC]] | coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LON|display=inline,title}} --> | origins = | key_people = Michael Huppe, President and CEO <ref name="Billboard Sirius Optimism">{{cite news|last1=Bliss|first1=Karen|title=SoundExchange CEO Points to SiriusXM's Growth for Royalty Rate Increase Optimism|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/business/7775025/soundexchange-michael-huppe-siriusxm-royaltiy-rates-crb|accessdate=15 December 2017|work=Billboard|date=April 25, 2017}}</ref> | area_served = International | products = | services = [[Royalties|Royalty]] distribution | focus = | mission = | method = | revenue = --- | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = 155,000 | subsid = | owner = | motto = | former name = | homepage = {{URL|www.soundexchange.com}} | dissolved = | footnotes = }} '''SoundExchange''' is a [[non-profit]] [[Collective rights management|collective rights management]] organization. It is the sole organization designated by the U.S. Congress to collect and distribute digital performance [[royalties]] for sound recordings. It pays featured and non-featured artists and master rights owners for the non-interactive use of sound recordings under the statutory licenses set forth in {{UnitedStatesCode|17|112}} and {{UnitedStatesCode|17|114}}.<ref name="MBW">{{cite news|last1=Ingham|first1=Tim|title=WHAT DOES THE FUTURE HOLD FOR SOUNDEXCHANGE?|url=https://www.musicbusinessworldwide.com/what-does-the-future-hold-for-soundexchange/|accessdate=6 December 2017|work=Music Business Worldwide|date=October 19, 2016}}</ref><ref name="Sisario">{{cite news|last1=Sisario|first1=Ben|title=Rise of SoundExchange Shows the Growth of Digital Radio Royalties|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/05/business/media/rise-of-soundexchange-shows-the-growth-of-digital-radio-royalties.html?_r=0|accessdate=6 December 2017|work=New York Times|date=August 4, 2015}}</ref>
Overseen by a board of directors composed of artists, artist representatives, and sound recording copyright owners, SoundExchange is also an advocate for music licensing reform.<ref name="Sisario">{{cite news|last1=Sisario|first1=Ben|title=Rise of SoundExchange Shows the Growth of Digital Radio Royalties|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/05/business/media/rise-of-soundexchange-shows-the-growth-of-digital-radio-royalties.html?_r=0|accessdate=6 December 2017|work=New York Times|date=August 4, 2015}}</ref> As of 2018 it had paid more than $5 billion to recording artists and rights owners.<ref name="Billboard 2018">{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/business/8093735/soundexchange-ceo-michael-huppe-contract-2021|title=SoundExchange Extends CEO Michael Huppe Through 2021|work=Billboard|access-date=2018-01-24}}</ref><ref name="HR 2018">{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2018/biz/news/soundexchange-passes-5-billion-mark-in-streaming-royalty-distributions-1202728206/|title=SoundExchange Passes $5 Billion Mark in Streaming Royalty Distributions|last=Staff|first=Variety|date=2018-03-15|work=Variety|access-date=2018-03-21|language=en-US}}</ref> ==History== SoundExchange was created as a division of the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]] in 2000. In 2001, major record labels and artists agreed on a standard for paying royalties earned from cable and satellite music services, and SoundExchange made its first payment, distributing $5.2 million in royalties to recording artists and labels. <ref name="Leeds 2001">{{cite news|last1=Leeds|first1=Jeff|title=Record Labels, Artists Reach Services Accord|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/nov/08/business/fi-1527|accessdate=2 January 2018|date=November 8, 2001}}</ref> In 2002, four years after the [[Digital Millennium Copyright Act]] granted webcasters an automatic license to play copyrighted music provided that a royalty was paid, a lengthy arbitration process was concluded, and a royalty rate was set. SoundExchange was spun off from the RIAA and became an independent non-profit corporation in 2003. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/06/21/business/technology-internet-radio-criticizes-rate-on-royalties.html|title=TECHNOLOGY; Internet Radio Criticizes Rate On Royalties|last=Harmon|first=Amy|date=2002-06-21|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-01-10|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/opinion/la-oew-healey11jun11-story.html|title=Battle Royalty|date=2007-06-11|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-01-10|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref>
SoundExchange's first executive director was John Simson, a musician, attorney, and artist manager.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/07/02/AR2007070201647.html|title=Jeffrey H. Birnbaum - Radio Royalties: Reprising Ol' Blue Eyes' Battle|last=Birnbaum|first=Jeffrey H.|date=2007-07-03|access-date=2018-01-10|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> Simson left the organization in 2011 and was replaced by Michael Huppe. In 2018 it was announced that the organization had extended his contract through 2021.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://musicrow.com/2018/01/soundexchange-board-extends-presidentceo-michael-huppes-contract/|title=SoundExchange Board Extends President/CEO Michael Huppe’s Contract|date=2018-01-10|work=MusicRow - Nashville's Music Industry Publication - News, Songs From Music City|access-date=2018-03-22|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name="Billboard 2018" /> He also serves as the chairman of the board of SXWorks, a subsidiary created by SoundExchange following its acquisition of the Canadian Musical Reproduction Rights Association (CMRRA). SXWorks provides administration and back office services to publishers to support multiple licensing configurations. <ref name="Billboard CMRRA">{{cite news|last1=Christman|first1=Ed|title=SoundExchange Is Officially Buying CMRRA, A Move Reflecting Evolving Digital Markets|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/business/7793209/soundexchange-buying-cmrra-reflects-evolving-markets|accessdate=6 November 2017|work=Billboard|date=May 15, 2017}}</ref>
In 2012, the company announced that it had paid over $1 billion in royalties since 2003.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/zackomalleygreenburg/2012/06/18/soundexchange-passes-1-billion-mark-in-music-royalties-paid/|title=SoundExchange Passes $1 Billion Mark In Music Royalties Paid|last=Greenburg|first=Zack O'Malley|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-03-22|language=en}}</ref>As of 2018, it had paid more than $5 billion,<ref name="HR 2018" /> with recording artists and rights holders paid $884 million in 2016 alone.<ref name="Billboard 2018" /><ref name="Billboard CMRRA">{{cite news|last1=Christman|first1=Ed|title=SoundExchange Is Officially Buying CMRRA, A Move Reflecting Evolving Digital Markets|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/business/7793209/soundexchange-buying-cmrra-reflects-evolving-markets|accessdate=6 November 2017|work=Billboard|date=May 15, 2017}}</ref>
==Purpose== SoundExchange exists to administer statutory licenses for sound recording copyrights, primarily through the collection and distribution of royalties for sound recording performances occurring under the jurisdiction of federal law. SoundExchange handles the following duties with respect to statutory licenses: *Collects performance royalties from the statutory licensees; *Collects and processes all data associated with the performance of the sound recordings; *Allocates royalties for the performance of the sound recording based on all of the data collected and processed; *Distributes the featured artist's share directly to the artist; *Distributes the copyright owner's share directly to the copyright owner; *Distributes the non-featured artist's share to [[SAG-AFTRA]] and [[American Federation of Musicians|AFM]]'s Intellectual Property Rights Distribution Fund; and *Provides detailed reports summarizing the titles, featured artists, and royalty amounts for each of the sound recordings performed by the statutory licensees.
An administrative fee is deducted from royalties before they are distributed, with the remainder divided between the performing artists on a given recording, and the copyright owner of that recording. SoundExchange collects and distributes royalties for all artists and copyright owners covered under the statutory licenses. It has collection agreements with more than 40 international performance rights organizations around the world,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.soundexchange.com/artist-copyright-owner/registration-membership/member-benefits/international-collection/|title=International Collection - SoundExchange|work=SoundExchange|access-date=2018-03-22|language=en-US}}</ref> allowing it to collect and pay royalties to recording artists and rights owners when their music is played in those countries. In 2017, SoundExchange expanded into music publisher administration with its acquisition of Canadian [[Mechanical rights|mechanical rights]] society CMRRA. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.musicbusinessworldwide.com/michael-huppe-signs-4-year-extension-remain-soundexchange-ceo/|title=Michael Huppe signs 4-year extension to continue as SoundExchange CEO - Music Business Worldwide|date=2018-01-10|work=Music Business Worldwide|access-date=2018-01-24|language=en-US}}</ref> ==Authority and structure== SoundExchange is designated by the [[Librarian of Congress]] as the sole organization authorized to collect royalties paid by services making ephemeral phonorecords or digital audio transmissions of sound recordings, or both, under the statutory licenses set forth in [[Title 17 of the United States Code|17 U.S.C.]] § 112 and [[Title 17 of the United States Code|17 U.S.C.]] § 114. As of January 1, 2003, SoundExchange is designated by the [[United States Copyright Office]] to also distribute the collected royalties to copyright owners and performers entitled under and pursuant to 17 U.S.C. § 114(g)(2). Incorporated in the State of Delaware, SoundExchange is exempt from taxation under Section 501(c)(6) of the Internal Revenue Code. It operates, in part, pursuant to Copyright Office regulations set forth in 37 C.F.R. Parts 370, 380, 382, 383 and 384.<ref name="notice_of_designation">{{cite web|url=http://www.copyright.gov/carp/notice-designation-collective.pdf|title=Notice of Designation As Collective Under Statutory License filed with the Licensing Division of the Copyright Office|accessdate=2008-10-16|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081030220250/http://www.copyright.gov/carp/notice-designation-collective.pdf|archivedate=2008-10-30|df=}}</ref>
SoundExchange is controlled by a Board of Directors composed of recording artists, representatives of recording artists and sound recording copyright owners. As of 2017, the board was composed of Duncan Crabtree-Ireland ([[SAG-AFTRA]]), Jay L. Cooper (attorney), Andrea Finkelstein (Sony Music Entertainment, Inc.), Ray Hair (American Federation of Musicians), Jeff Harleston (Universal Music Group), Michael Hausman (artist manager), Steve Marks (RIAA), [[David Byrne]] (artist), Kendall Minter (attorney), Richard Burgess (American Association of Independent Music), Patrick Rains (artist manager, PRA Records), [[Martha Reeves]] (artist), Perry Resnick (RZO Royalty Management), Paul Robinson (Warner Music Group), Cary Sherman (RIAA), Darius Van Arman (Secretly Group), Ron Wilcox (Warner Music Group) and Victor Zaraya (Razor & Tie).<ref name="BoD">{{cite web|title=Board of Directors|url=https://www.soundexchange.com/about/our-team/board-of-directors/|website=soundexchange.com|publisher=SoundExchange|accessdate=6 November 2017}}</ref> ==Royalty rate setting== As required by {{UnitedStatesCode|17|112}} and {{UnitedStatesCode|17|114}}, SoundExchange, along with other interested parties, participates in each periodic rate-making proceedings to establish rates that compensate copyright owners and performers for the use of copyrighted sound recordings. Such rate setting proceedings may be resolved through proceedings through the Copyright Royalty Board (CRB).<ref name="Sirius settlement 2017">{{cite news|last1=Steele|first1=Anne|title=Sirius XM Satellite Radio to Pay Higher Royalty Rate Starting in 2018|url=http://news.morningstar.com/all/dow-jones/us-markets/201712156584/sirius-xm-satellite-radio-to-pay-higher-royalty-rate-starting-in-2018.aspx|accessdate=15 December 2017|work=Dow Jones (via Morningstar)|date=December 15, 2017}}</ref> ===Satellite radio=== In December 2017, the Copyright Royalty Board (CRB) increased the [[Sirius XM]] royalty rate from 11.5% of revenue to 15.5% of revenue through 2022.<ref name="Billboard Sirius Optimism">{{cite news|last1=Bliss|first1=Karen|title=SoundExchange CEO Points to SiriusXM's Growth for Royalty Rate Increase Optimism|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/business/7775025/soundexchange-michael-huppe-siriusxm-royaltiy-rates-crb|accessdate=15 December 2017|work=Billboard|date=April 25, 2017}}</ref> The CRB also rendered a decision on royalty rates paid by [[Muzak]] and [[Music Choice]] in December 2017, reducing the royalty rates paid by those services from 8.5% of revenue to 7.5% of revenue. <ref name="BB muzak">{{cite news|last1=Flanagan|first1=Andrew|title=SoundExchange Files Its Second Lawsuit Over Improper Royalties|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/business/6524108/soundexchange-second-lawsuit-muzak-mood-media|accessdate=2 January 2018|work=Billboard|date=April 3, 2015}}</ref>
In 2015 SoundExchange sued Muzak for underpayments of royalties to artists and rights holders. Because its royalty rate was established before the DMCA was enacted, Muzak's streaming services to [[Dish Network]] subscribers was allowed a grandfathered rate standard that resulted in lower royalty rates. The SoundExchange lawsuit sought to implement the standard royalty rate for new subscriptions on Muzak’s streaming services to other cable/satellite TV providers. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/brief-mood-media-announces-update-to-cou/brief-mood-media-announces-update-to-court-proceedings-involving-its-subsidiary-muzak-llc-idUSASA09KE0|title=BRIEF-Mood media announces update to court proceedings involving its subsidiary MuzakLLC|date=April 26, 2017|work=Reuters|access-date=2018-01-10}}</ref> ===Webcasting=== The CRB judges established webcasting rates on December 16, 2015, for the 2016-2020 term – $0.0017 for non-subscription performances and $0.0020 for subscription performances for commercial webcasters in 2017, with rates for each subsequent year adjusted upward or downward, according to the Consumer Price Index for the year. As of 2018, webcasting rates were $0.0018 for non-subscription services and $0.0023 for subscription services.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.broadcastlawblog.com/2015/12/articles/crb-announces-webcasting-royalty-rates-for-2016-2020-lower-rates-for-broadcasters-who-stream-minimal-change-for-pureplay-webcasters/|title=CRB Announces Webcasting Royalty Rates for 2016-2020 – Lower Rates for Broadcasters Who Stream, Minimal Change for Pureplay Webcasters {{!}} Broadcast Law Blog|date=2015-12-17|work=Broadcast Law Blog|access-date=2018-01-24|language=en-US}}</ref> ==Advocacy efforts== SoundExchange is an advocate for the reform of U.S. music licensing laws, seeking to ensure that music creators earn fair market value for their work when it is used on any music platform. During the 115<sup>th</sup> Congress, SoundExchange actively supported the Fair Play Fair Pay Act of 2017 (H.R.1836) and the [[CLASSICS Act]] (H.R.3301). It is a founding member of musicFIRST, a coalition of organizations representing musicians, recording artists, managers, music businesses, and performance rights advocates. <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/posts/la-et-ms-fair-play-fair-pay-act-congress-radio-royalties-20150413-story.html|title=Fair Play, Fair Pay Act of 2015 would require radio to pay for music|last=Lewis|first=Randy|date=2015-04-13|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-01-08|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newyorker.com/news/daily-comment/congresss-chance-to-be-fair-to-musicians|title=Congress’s Chance to Be Fair to Musicians|last=Tobin|first=Jeffrey|date=2016-05-18|work=The New Yorker|access-date=2018-01-08|issn=0028-792X}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2017/biz/news/fair-play-fair-pay-radio-royalty-act-gains-momentum-1202462359/|title=‘Fair Play, Fair Pay’ Radio-Royalty Act Gains Momentum, But Faces Uphill Climb|last=Parisi|first=Paula|date=2017-06-12|work=Variety|access-date=2018-01-07|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.recode.net/2015/2/5/11558712/copyright-office-has-thoughts-on-what-streaming-music-services-should|title=Copyright Office Has Thoughts on What Streaming Music Services Should Pay for Music|work=Recode|access-date=2018-01-09}}</ref>
==Projects and initiatives== In March 2016 SoundExchange introduced an online service to allow music services to locate [[Metadata|metadata]] for 20 million sound recordings in its database. The service allows users to search SoundExchange’s database of international standard recording rates, unique identifiers for sound recordings.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6898444/soundexchange-isrc-tool|title=SoundExchange Debuts Search Tool for Song Codes|work=Billboard|access-date=2018-01-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hypebot.com/hypebot/2016/03/soundexchange-launches-free-20-million-song-search-database.html|title=SoundExchange Launches Free 20 Million Song Search Database|website=hypebot|access-date=2018-01-24}}</ref>
In January 2018 the SoundExchange subsidiary SXWorks launched NOI (Notice of Intention) Lookup. It allows songwriters and publishers to search a U.S. copyright database which indexes "Address Unknown" notices, the term used when a music service files an intention to use a musical work, but claims that they cannot locate the copyright owner. A free tool, it allows copyright owners to identify their work. In 2017, an average of 2.5 million monthly address unknown NOI filings were submitted to the US Copyright Office by music services. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.musicbusinessworldwide.com/soundexchanges-sxworks-launches-free-tool-to-fix-widespread-noi-copyright-problem-in-the-us/|title=SoundExchange's SXWorks launches free tool to fix widespread NOI copyright problem in the US - Music Business Worldwide|date=2018-01-23|work=Music Business Worldwide|access-date=2018-01-24|language=en-US}}</ref> ==Criticism== A 2007 royalty rate increase was reported as establishing a rate that would "render Internet radio unsustainable, or at the very least, more ad-laden than terrestrial radio." <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/2007/03/us-copyright-ro/|title=U.S. Copyright Royalty Board Rejects Webcasters, Embraces SoundExchange|work=WIRED|access-date=2018-01-24|language=en-US}}</ref> Critics charged that in negotiating the royalty, SoundExchange was concerned primarily with major labels and their artists.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=9163084|title=New Royalty Rules May Reshape Internet Radio|work=NPR.org|access-date=2018-01-24|language=en}}</ref> Thousands of internet broadcasters participated in a "day of silence" protest by cancelling their programming on June 26, 2007.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/06/25/AR2007062501801.html|title=Web Radio Stations Hope Silence Speaks Volumes About Fee Hike|last=Musgrove|first=Mike|date=2007-06-26|access-date=2018-01-24|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref> ==See also== *[[Performance rights organization]] *[[Copyright Royalty Board]]

The '''Sydney APEC Leaders' Declaration on Climate Change, Energy Security and Clean Development''' was adopted at [[APEC Australia 2007]] on 8 September 2007.<ref>''[http://www.smh.com.au/news/apec/sydney-declaration-on-climate-change-and-energy/2007/09/09/1189276526002.html?page=fullpage#contentSwap2 Sydney Declaration on Climate Change and Energy]'', Sydney Morning Herald, 9 September 2007. See also ''[http://www.smh.com.au/pdf/leadersstatement.pdf Leaders Statement (PDF)]'' Accessed 12 September 2008</ref>
The agreement indicates the wish of signatories to work towards aspirational goals on energy efficiency per unit of [[GDP]] while encouraging [[forest cover]] in the region. The APEC wide regional aspirational goal is to reduce energy intensity by at least 25 percent by 2030 from the 2005 level, and set an APEC-wide regional goal of increasing forest cover in the region by 200,000 square kilometres by 2020.<ref>''[http://www.theage.com.au/news/national/apec-climate-agreement-a-diplomatic-breakthrough/2007/09/09/1189276521977.html APEC climate agreement a 'diplomatic breakthrough]'', The Age, 9 September 2007. Accessed 12 September 2008</ref>
==Criticism== Environmental and climate organisations such as [[Greenpeace]], the [[Australian Conservation Foundation]] and the [[Climate Action Network]] criticised the agreement for not setting binding targets on [[greenhouse gas emissions]] for developed countries, and that the statement was little more than a political stunt.<ref>''[http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2007/09/09/2027701.htm Govt, green groups face off over Sydney Declaration]'' ABC News, 9 September 2007. Accessed 12 September 2008</ref><ref>Greenpeace media release, ''[http://www.greenpeace.org/australia/news-and-events/media/releases/climate-change/apec-declaration-a-sydney-dist APEC declaration a Sydney distraction from action on climate change]'', Greenpeace website, 8 September 2007. Accessed 12 September 2008</ref>
[[Greenpeace]] pointed out that Foreign Minister [[Alexander Downer]] told an APEC lecture in Melbourne in April 2007 that aspirational targets are a "political stunt" and "not a real target at all".<ref>Liz Micnchin, ''[http://www.theage.com.au/news/national/q-when-is-a-stunt-not-a-stunt-a-when-the-boss-likes-the-idea/2007/09/06/1188783413265.html Q: When is a stunt not a stunt? A: When the boss likes the idea]'', The Age, 7 September 2007. Accessed 12 September 2008</ref> One Greenpeace spokesperson said the declaration should be named the "'''Sydney Distraction'''" on climate change.<ref>Adam Gartrell, ''[http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,22384889-5005961,00.html Greenpeace slams APEC climate pact]'', Herald Sun, 8 September 2007. Accessed 12 September 2008</ref>
The [[Australian Conservation Foundation]] called the declaration "very weak" and said the "declaration does not advance global discussions on climate change."<ref>Australian Conservation Foundation Meadia Release, ''[http://www.acfonline.org.au/articles/news.asp?news_id=1408 APEC’s Sydney Declaration is weak on climate ]'' Australian Conservation Foundation website, 8 September 2007. Accessed 12 September 2008</ref>

{{Refimprove|date=August 2014}} {{IPstack}} A '''TXT record''' (short for '''text record''') is a type of [[Domain Name System#DNS resource records|resource record]] in the [[Domain Name System]] (DNS) used to provide the ability to associate arbitrary text with a host or other name, such as human readable information about a server, network, data center, or other accounting information.{{cite IETF|title=RFC 1464 Using the Domain Name System To Store Arbitrary String Attributes|rfc=1464|author= Rich Rosenbaum|url=https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1464|year=1993|month=May|accessdate=2016-02-05|publisher=[[Internet Engineering Task Force|IETF]]}} ==Usage== A domain may have multiple TXT records associated with it, provided the DNS server implementation supports this.{{cite web|url=https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1464|title=Using the Domain Name System To Store Arbitrary String Attributes|first=R.|last=Rosenbaum|website=Tools.ietf.org|accessdate=14 October 2018}} Each record can in turn have one or more character strings.{{cite IETF |section=3.3.14 |sectionname=TXT RDATA format |title=Domain names - implementation and specification | rfc=1035 |year=1987 |month=November |author=P. Mockapetris |publisher=[[Internet Engineering Task Force|IETF]]}} Common uses include verification of domain ownership; implementation of [[Sender Policy Framework]],{{cite IETF |title=Sender Policy Framework (SPF) for Authorizing Use of Domains in Email, Version 1 |rfc=7208 |sectionname=DNS Resource Records |section=3.1 |author=Scott Kitterman |year=2014 |month=April |publisher=[[Internet Engineering Task Force|IETF]] |accessdate=2014-04-26 }} [[DomainKeys]], or [[DomainKeys Identified Mail]] records for verifying the sender of [[email]] messages;{{cite web|title=About TXT records|url=https://support.google.com/a/answer/2716800|website=Google Apps Administration|publisher=Google|accessdate=2014-08-17}} and [[Zero-configuration networking#DNS-based service discovery|Zero-configuration networking DNS-based service discovery]].{{cite IETF |rfc=6762 |year=2013 |month=February |author=S. Cheshire and M. Krochmal, Apple Inc. |title=Multicast DNS |publisher=[[Internet Engineering Task Force|IETF]]}}{{cite IETF |rfc=6763 |year=2013 |month=February |author=S. Cheshire and M. Krochmal, Apple Inc. |title=DNS-Based Service Discovery |publisher=[[Internet Engineering Task Force|IETF]]}} == Format == To store new types of information, the experimental RFC 1464 suggests a structured format in TXT data fields. The format consists of the attribute name followed by the value of the attribute. The name and value are separated by an equals sign (=). The general syntax is: 
   TXT "="
Example: 
name  class   ttl    rr     text
joe    IN           TXT    "Located in a black hole=Likely to be eaten by a grue"
# '''Name''': This is the host for the domain, which is actually a computer within the domain. The domain name is automatically appended to the host name. To make a record for the system www.example.com, the name value is just "www". If the name field is left blank, it will default to be the record for the base domain. The record for the base domain is called the ''root record'' or ''apex record''. # '''Value''': This can be free form text data of any type. Each word is treated as a separate string unless one or more strings are enclosed in quotes. The maximum length of a string is 255 bytes, but any number of strings can be present in each record, subject to the standard DNS RDATA size limit of 65,535 bytes.{{Cite web |url=https://lists.isc.org/pipermail/bind-users/2009-March/075931.html# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2017-02-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151019200112/https://lists.isc.org/pipermail/bind-users/2009-March/075931.html# |archive-date=2015-10-19 |dead-url=yes |df= }} # '''TTL''': The TTL (Time to Live) is the amount of time, in seconds, the record will stay in cache on systems requesting your record (resolving nameservers, browsers, etc.). === Attribute name matching rules === The attribute name is considered case-insensitive. During lookups, TXT records that do not contain an unquoted "=" are ignored. TXT records that seem to contain a null attribute name, that is, the TXT-DATA starts with the character "=", are also ignored. Leading and trailing whitespace (spaces and tabs) in the attribute name are ignored unless they are quoted with a backtick (`). Note that most DNS server implementations require a backslash (\) or double quote (") in a text string to be quoted with a preceding backslash. The backtick (`) was chosen as a quoting character in this syntax to avoid confusion with backslash (\) (and remove the need for confusing strings that include sequences like "\\\\"). === Attribute values === All printable ASCII characters are permitted in the attribute value. No characters need to be quoted with a backtick (`). In other words, the first unquoted equals sign in the TXT record is the name/value delimiter. All subsequent characters are part of the value. ==See also== * [[Author Domain Signing Practices]] * [[DMARC|Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting and Conformance (DMARC)]] * [[DomainKeys Identified Mail|DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM)]] * [[E-mail authentication]] * [[List of DNS record types]] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Internet architecture]] [[Category:Network addressing]] [[Category:Internet governance]] [[Category:Internet protocols]] [[Category:Internet Standards]] [[Category:Application layer protocols]] [[Category:DNS record types]] [[Category:Email authentication]] [[Category:Spam filtering]]

{{Infobox person | name = Tim Wu | image = Tim_Wu.jpg | alt = Tim Wu, 2017 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth based on age as of date |42 |2014|July|27}}{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/ivy-league-power-propels-columbias-tim-wu-in-bid-to-be-new-yorks-lieutenant-governor-1406513014|title=Ivy League Power Propels Columbia's Tim Wu in Bid to be New York's Lieutenant Governor >|last=Ante |first=Spencer E.|date=27 July 2014|website=wsj.com|publisher=''[[Wall Street Journal]]''|access-date=27 July 2016}} | birth_place = [[Washington, D.C.]], US | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = | party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] | alma_mater = [[McGill University]]
[[Harvard Law School]] | other_names = | spouse = Kate Judge | children = 2 | occupation = Professor at [[Columbia Law School]] | known_for = Coining the term "[[net neutrality]]" | website = {{official URL}} }} {{Chinese|pic=|piccap=Tim Wu at a Campaign Event|t=吳修銘|s=吴修铭|p=Wú Xiūmíng|w=Wu2 Hsiu1-ming2|mi={{IPAc-cmn|wu|2|-|x|iu|1|m|ing|2}}}} '''Tim Wu''' is an American lawyer, professor at [[Columbia Law School]], and contributing opinion writer for the [[New York Times]]. He is best known for coining the phrase [[network neutrality]] in his 2003 paper ''Network Neutrality, Broadband Discrimination'',{{Cite journal | last1 = Wu | first1 = T. | doi = 10.2139/ssrn.388863 | title = Network Neutrality, Broadband Discrimination | journal =Journal of Telecommunications and High Technology Law | year = 2003 |volume=2 |pages=141–179 | pmid = | pmc = | ssrn=388863}} and popularizing the concept thereafter. Wu has also made significant contributions to [[Antitrust law|antitrust]] policy and [[wireless]] communications policy, most notably with his "[[Carterfone]]" proposal.{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/bwdaily/dnflash/content/nov2007/db2007117_264711.htm|title=Tim Wu, Freedom Fighter|last=Ante|first=Spencer E.|date=8 November 2008|website=|publisher=''[[BusinessWeek]]''|access-date=}} Wu is a scholar of the media and technology industries, and his academic specialties include antitrust, [[copyright]], and telecommunications law. Wu was named to ''[[The National Law Journal]]''{{'}}s "America's 100 Most Influential Lawyers" in 2013, as well as to the "[[Politico]] 50" in 2014 and 2015. Additionally, Wu was named one of ''[[Scientific American]]'''s 50 people of the year in 2006, and one of [[Harvard University]]'s 100 most influential graduates by ''[[02138]]'' magazine in 2007.{{cite web|url=http://www.oecdministerialseoul2008.org/en/programmee/speaker_view.html?id=16 |title=Tim Wu |first= |last= |accessdate=10 December 2008 |publisher=[[OECD]] Ministerial Meeting on the Future of the Internet Economy, June 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090118043729/http://www.oecdministerialseoul2008.org/en/programmee/speaker_view.html?id=16 |archivedate=January 18, 2009 }} His book ''The Master Switch'' was named among the best books of 2010 by ''[[The New Yorker]]'' magazine,{{cite web | url = http://www.newyorker.com/arts/reviews/brieflynoted/2010/12/13/101213crbn_brieflynoted |title= Reviewer's Favorites |work = [[The New Yorker]]}} ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'' magazine,{{cite news |url=http://money.cnn.com/2010/12/22/technology/bell_systems_master_switch.fortune/index.htm |title = America's Original Startup |publisher=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] | first1=Tim |last1=Wu |date=2010-12-22}} ''[[Publishers Weekly]]'',{{cite web |url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/book-news/awards-and-prizes/article/45070-best-books-of-2010.html?page=5 |title = Best Books of 2010 |work=[[Publishers Weekly]]}} and other publications. From 2011 to 2012, Wu served as a Senior Advisor to the [[Federal Trade Commission]],[http://www.law.columbia.edu/media_inquiries/news_events/2011/february2011/timwu-ftc "Professor Tim Wu Named Advisor to Federal Trade Commission on Consumer Protection, Competition"], ''Columbia University Public Affairs'', New York, Feb. 8, 2011 and from 2015–2016 he was senior enforcement counsel and special advisor at the [[New York Attorney General|New York Office of the Attorney General]]. In 2016 Wu joined the National Economic Council in the Obama White House to work on competition policy.http://www.politico.com/tipsheets/morning-tech/2016/08/net-neutrality-advocate-tim-wu-joins-white-house-215945 ==Early life== Wu was born in [[Washington, D.C.]]{{cite web|url=https://generalassemb.ly/instructors/tim-wu/2938 |title=TIM WU |publisher=General Assembly |date= |accessdate=September 10, 2014 }} and grew up in [[Basel, Switzerland]], and [[Toronto, Ontario]], [[Canada]].{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/11/business/defending-the-open-internet.html?_r=0 |title=Defending the Open Internet |publisher=''The New York Times'' |date=May 10, 2014 |first=Jeff |last=Sommer |accessdate=September 10, 2014 }} His father, Alan Ming-ta Wu, was from [[Taiwan]] and his mother, [[Gillian E. Wu|Gillian Wu]],{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2014/09/06/toronto-superstar-academic-who-coined-net-neutrality-could-be-nominee-for-n-y-lieutenant-governor/ |title=Toronto superstar academic who coined 'net-neutrality' could be nominee for N.Y. lieutenant-governor |publisher=''National Post'' |date=September 6, 2014 |first=Richard |last=Warnica }} is British-Canadian.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/01/nyregion/inspired-by-his-fathers-activism-an-outsider-seeks-statewide-office.html |title=Inspired by His Father's Activism, Tim Wu Is Running for Lieutenant Governor as an Outsider |publisher=''The New York Times'' |date=August 31, 2014 |first=David W. |last=Chen |accessdate=September 10, 2014 }} They both studied as immunologists at the [[University of Toronto]].{{cite news|url=http://www.businessweek.com/print/bwdaily/dnflash/content/nov2007/db2007117_264711.htm|title=Tim Wu, Freedom Fighter|last=Ante|first=Spencer E.|date=2007-11-08|publisher=[[BusinessWeek]]}} Wu and his younger brother were sent to alternative schools that emphasized creativity. At school, he befriended [[Cory Doctorow]]. Wu's father died in 1980 and his mother bought him and his brother an [[Apple II]] computer using some of the insurance money, starting Wu's fascination with [[computers]]. Wu attended [[McGill University]], where he initially studied biochemistry and later switched his major to biophysics. He graduated from McGill with a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in 1995 and received his law degree from [[Harvard Law School]] in 1998. At Harvard, he studied under copyright scholar [[Lawrence Lessig]]. ==Academic career== Wu worked with the U.S. Department of Justice, Office of Legal Counsel, after graduating from law school, and before starting a clerkship with [[Richard Posner]] on the [[Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals]] in 1998-1999.{{cite web |url=http://www.law.columbia.edu/fac/Timothy_Wu |title=Tim Wu |publisher=[[Columbia University]] School of Law}} He also clerked for [[Justice Stephen Breyer|Stephen Breyer]], [[United States Supreme Court|U.S. Supreme Court]] in 1999-2000. Following his clerkships, Wu moved to the [[San Francisco Bay Area]], worked at [[Riverstone Networks]], Inc. (2000–02){{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/business/article/Net-neutrality-guru-to-speak-at-USF-3231050.php |title=Net neutrality guru to speak at USF |publisher=''San Francisco Chronicle'' |date=January 25, 2008 |first=Ryan |last=Kim |accessdate=September 11, 2014 }} and then entered academia at the [[University of Virginia School of Law]]. Wu was Associate Professor of Law at the [[University of Virginia]] from 2002 to 2004, Visiting Professor at [[Columbia Law School]] in 2004, Visiting Professor at [[Chicago Law School]] in 2005, and Visiting Professor at [[Stanford Law School]] in 2005.{{cite web |url=http://www.law.columbia.edu/fac/Timothy_Wu |title=Tim Wu | first= |last= |accessdate=10 December 2008 |publisher=Columbia Law School}} In 2006, he became a full professor at [[Columbia Law School]]{{cite web|url=http://observer.com/2006/11/wuhoo-nutty-professor-is-voice-of-a-generation/ |title=Wu-Hoo! Nutty Professor Is Voice of a Generation |publisher=''New York Observer'' |date=November 20, 2006 |first=Anna |last=Schneider-Mayerson |accessdate=September 11, 2014 }} and started Project Posner, a free database of all of [[Richard Posner]]'s legal opinions.{{cite news| title = A Paean to the Opinions of the Prolific Judge Posner| publisher = ''The Wall Street Journal'' Law Blog| date = 2006-10-06| url = https://blogs.wsj.com/law/2006/10/10/a-paean-to-the-opinions-of-the-prolific-judge-posner/| accessdate = 2008-10-17 | first=Peter | last=Lattman}} Wu called Posner "probably America's greatest living jurist." ==Influence== [[File:Wikipedia Day New York January 2017 003.jpg|thumb|left|Wu speaks on a panel at [[Wikipedia Day]] 2017.]] Wu is credited with popularizing the concept of [[network neutrality]] in his 2003 paper ''Network Neutrality, Broadband Discrimination''. The paper considered network neutrality in terms of neutrality between applications, as well as neutrality between data and Quality of Service-sensitive traffic, and proposed some legislation to potentially deal with these issues.{{cite web|url=http://www.freepress.net/docs/timwu.pdf|title=Network Neutrality, Broadband Discrimination |first=Tim |last=Wu|publisher=|accessdate=27 October 2017}}{{cite web |url=http://www.law.columbia.edu/media_inquiries/news_events/2008/april2008/Wu_FreePress |title=Tim Wu Elected Board Chair At Free Press | first= |last= |date=14 April 2008 |publisher=Columbia Law School }} In 2006, Wu wrote "The World Trade Law of Internet Filtering", which analyzed the possibility of the [[World Trade Organization]]'s treating [[censorship]] as a [[trade barrier|barrier to trade]].{{cite web|last=Wu|first=Tim|title=The World Trade Law of Internet Filtering|ssrn=882459|date=2006-05-06|publisher=[[SSRN]]}} In June 2007, when [[Google Inc.]] lobbied the [[United States Trade Representative]] to pursue a complaint against China's censorship at the WTO, Wu's paper was cited as a "likely source" for this idea.{{cite news|title=Google Fights Internet Censorship|last=Rugaber|first=Christopher S.|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/06/25/AR2007062500364_pf.html|publisher=Washington Post|date=2007-06-25}} In 2006, Wu was also invited by the [[Federal Communications Commission]] (FCC) to help draft the first [[network neutrality]] rules attached to the [[AT&T]] and [[BellSouth]] merger. In 2007, Wu published a paper proposing a "Wireless [[Carterfone]]" rule for [[mobile phone]] networks;{{cite journal|last=Wu|first=Tim|year=2007|title=Wireless Carterfone|journal=International Journal of Communication|pages=389–426|url=http://ijoc.org/ojs/index.php/ijoc/article/viewFile/152/96|accessdate= 2007-11-09}} the rule was adopted on July 31, 2007 by the [[Federal Communications Commission]] for the [[United States 2008 wireless spectrum auction]], with FCC Commissioner [[Michael Copps]] stating: "I find it extremely heartening to see that an academic paper—in this case by Professor Timothy Wu of Columbia Law School—can have such an immediate and forceful influence on policy."{{Cite pressrelease|title=Statement of FCC Commissioner Michael J. Copps on the 700 MHz Service Rules|url=http://www.freepress.net/news/25059|work=[[Free Press (publisher)|Free Press]] Newsroom|publisher=''freepress.net'' ([[Free Press (organization)|Free Press]])|date=2007-07-31|accessdate=2008-08-24}} In November 2007 [[BusinessWeek]] credited Wu with providing "the intellectual framework that inspired Google's mobile phone strategy." With his [[Columbia Law School]] colleagues Professors Scott Hemphill and Clarisa Long, Wu co-directs the Columbia Law School Program on Law and Technology, founded in 2007.{{cite web|title=Program on Law and Technology at Columbia University School of Law|url=http://www.law.columbia.edu/center_program?&main.ctrl=contentmgr.detail&&main2.view=static.null&main.view=programs.detail&main.id=10267|work=Programs & Centers|publisher=[[Columbia University]]|accessdate=2008-08-24}}{{cite web|url=http://www.columbialawtech.org/|title=Program on Law and Technology at Columbia University School of Law|work=columbialawtech.org|publisher=[[Columbia Law School]], [[Columbia University]]|accessdate=2008-08-24}} In August 2007, in collaboration with the [[University of Colorado School of Law]]'s Silicon Flatirons Program, the Columbia Law School Program on Law and Technology launched a [[Beta version|Beta]] version of [[AltLaw]], which he produced.{{cite web|title=About AltLaw|url=http://www.altlaw.org/v1/about|accessdate=2008-08-24|quote=Written by Stuart Sierra and Paul Ohm, with help from Luis Villa and Dana Powers, and produced by Tim Wu. |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080713095322/http://www.altlaw.org/v1/about |archivedate = 2008-07-13}} Wu has appeared on the television programs ''[[The Colbert Report]]''{{Citation|title=End of Net Neutrality - Tim Wu-The Colbert Report - Video Clip {{!}} Comedy Central|url=http://thecolbertreport.cc.com/videos/qatuhg/end-of-net-neutrality---tim-wu|accessdate=2016-07-18}} and ''[[Charlie Rose (TV series)|Charlie Rose]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/205383|title=Charlie Rose|website=Hulu|accessdate=27 October 2017}} ==''The Master Switch''== Wu's 2010 book ''The Master Switch: The Rise and Fall of Information Empires'' described a long "cycle" whereby open information systems become consolidated and closed over time, reopening only after disruptive innovation. The book shows this cycle develop with the rise of the Bell [[AT&T Corporation|AT&T]] telephone monopoly, the founding of the Hollywood entertainment industry, broadcast and cable TV industries, and finally with the internet industry. He looks at the example of [[Apple Inc.]], which began as a company dedicated to openness that evolved into a more closed system under the leadership of [[Steve Jobs]], demonstrating that the internet industry will follow the historical cycle of the rise of Information empires (though Wu discuss Google as an important counterpoint). The book was named one of the best books of 2010 by ''The New Yorker'' magazine, ''Fortune'' magazine, Amazon.com,{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/gp/feature.html?ie=UTF8&plgroup=1&docId=1000628041 |title= Best Books of 2010 |publisher=[[Amazon.com]]}} ''The Washington Post'',{{cite news |url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/ezra-klein/2010/12/the_five_best_books_i_read_thi.html |title = The five best books I read this year | publisher=Washington Post}} ''Publishers Weekly'', and others. == New York politics == [[File:Tim Wu, Campaign Event, Summer 2014.jpg|thumb|at a campaign event]] {{main|New York gubernatorial election, 2014}} Wu ran for the Democratic nomination for [[Lieutenant Governor of New York]] in 2014, campaigning alongside gubernatorial candidate [[Zephyr Teachout]].[https://www.buzzfeed.com/jacobfischler/zephyr-teachout-challenges-andrew-cuomo "zephyr-teachout-challenges-andrew-cuomo"], ''buzzfeed.com'' Wu and Teachout ran against [[Andrew Cuomo]], the incumbent governor, and [[Kathy Hochul]], an upstate Democrat and former Representative in the House. Teachout and Wu ran to the left of Cuomo and Hochul. Hochul won the race for Lieutenant Governor; Wu took 40% of the popular vote.{{cite web|url=http://project.wnyc.org/election2014-ny-state/|title=Election 2014 - WNYC|first=WNYC Data|last=News|website=project.wnyc.org|accessdate=27 October 2017}} In a ''Washington Post'' interview discussing his candidacy, Wu described his approach to the campaign as one positioned against the concentration of private power: "A hundred years ago, antitrust and merger enforcement was front page news. And we live in another era of enormous private concentration. And for some reason we call all these 'wonky issues.' They're not, really. They affect people more than half a dozen other issues. Day to day, people's lives are affected by concentration and infrastructure... You can expect a progressive-style, trust-busting kind of campaign out of me. And I fully intend to bridge that gap between the kind of typical issues in electoral politics and questions involving private power."Fung, Brian (June 16, 2014). "[https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-switch/wp/2014/06/16/15-questions-for-tim-wu-the-net-neutrality-scholar-whos-running-for-n-y-lieutenant-governor 15 questions for Tim Wu, the net neutrality scholar who’s running for N.Y. lieutenant governor]". ''Washington Post''. washingtonpost.com. Retrieved 2014-04-16. ''The New York Times'' editorial board endorsed Wu for lieutenant governor in the [[New York gubernatorial election, 2014#Democratic primary|Democratic Party primary]], although they offered no endorsement for the office of governor.[https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/28/opinion/timothy-wu-for-lieutenant-governor.html "Timothy Wu for Lieutenant Governor"], editorial, ''The New York Times'', August 27, 2014. Retrieved 2014-08-28.[https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/27/opinion/editorial-governor-cuomo-ethics-reform-hinders-endorsement-zephyr-teachout.html "The Governor’s Primary in New York: Governor Cuomo’s Failure on Ethics Reform Hinders an Endorsement"], editorial, ''The New York Times'', August 26, 2014. Retrieved 2014-08-30. In September 2015, ''The New York Times'' reported Wu's appointment to the Office of New York State Attorney General [[Eric Schneiderman]].{{Cite news|title = Tim Wu, Open Internet Advocate, Joins New York Attorney General's Office|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/14/nyregion/tim-wu-open-internet-advocate-joins-new-york-attorney-generals-office.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2015-09-13|access-date = 2015-12-07|issn = 0362-4331|first = Thomas|last = Kaplan}} Wu works on issues involving technology, including protecting consumers and ensuring fair competition among companies that do business online. == Personal life == Wu is married to Kate Judge, also a Columbia Law professor. '''Tyke''' (1974 – August 20, 1994) was an [[African bush elephant]] from [[Mozambique]] who performed with Circus International of [[Honolulu]], [[Hawaii]]. On August 20, 1994, during a performance at the [[Neal Blaisdell Center]], she killed her trainer, [[Allen Campbell]], and seriously injured her groomer, Dallas Beckwith. Tyke then bolted from the arena and ran through the streets of the [[Kakaako]] central business district for more than thirty minutes. Unable to calm the elephant, local police eventually opened fire on the animal, which eventually collapsed from the wounds and died. While the majority of the attack in the arena was recorded on consumer videotape by several spectators, additional professional video footage captured the attack on local publicist Steve Hirano and the shooting of Tyke herself (both of which took place outside of the building).
== Background == According to Tyrone Taylor, Tyke's responsible trainer at the time (interviewed in documentary film), Tyke had been involved in three incidents prior to the attack of August 1994.<ref name=TykeElephantOutlaw>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt4254838/ |title=Documentary: Tyke Elephant Outlaw (2015 Lambert, Moore)}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.afi.com/tyke-elephant-outlaw-co-directors-susan-lambert-and-stefan-moore/ |title=The film TYKE ELEPHANT OUTLAW}}</ref>
===April 21–22, 1993=== On April 21, 1993, Tyke escaped through the front doors of the [[Altoona, Pennsylvania]] [[Jaffa Shrine Center]] during a performance, remaining untethered for an hour. The rampage caused more than $14,000 in damage. An [[affidavit]] obtained from a circus worker by the [[United States Department of Agriculture|USDA]] the following day stated that Tyke had also attacked a tiger trainer, while the circus was in Altoona.<ref name=PetaFactsheet>{{cite web|url=http://www.circuses.com/fact-hawthorn.asp |title=Factsheet: Hawthorn Corporation (John Cuneo) |website=Peta.org |date= |format=PDF |accessdate=2013-07-08}}</ref>
===July 23, 1993=== On July 23, 1993, Tyke "ran amok at the [[North Dakota State Fair]] in [[Minot, North Dakota]], trampling and injuring a handler and frightening the crowd as [she] ran uncontrolled for 25 minutes".
According to USDA and Canadian law enforcement documents, while a Hawthorn elephant named Tyke (possibly the same Tyke involved in the four aforementioned incidents), was performing with Tarzan Zerbini Circus, "The elephant handler was observed beating the single-tusk African elephant in public to the point [where] the elephant was screaming and bending down on three legs to avoid being hit. Even when the handler walked by the elephant after this, the elephant screamed and veered away, demonstrating fear from his presence."<ref name=PetaFactsheet/>
== Casualties == On August 20, 1994, during a performance at Circus International in [[Honolulu, Hawaii]], Tyke trampled and critically injured her groomer, Dallas Beckwith, throwing him around numerous times in the process, before killing her trainer, [[Allen Campbell]], who was knocked to the ground, dragged and crushed to death under Tyke's massive trunk after he attempted to save Beckwith from being trampled to death during the attack. She then charged out of the arena and onto the streets outside. She additionally attacked and nearly crushed [[publicist]] Steve Hirano, who tried to stop her from escaping from the circus' parking lot. A nearby police officer seeing the attack fired multiple shots in the direction of the elephant, distracting her and causing her to flee away from Hirano. After a half-hour of chasing Tyke down, local police officers fired more than 86 shots at the {{convert|8,000|lb|kg}} elephant. Tyke finally collapsed from the numerous wounds and died.<ref>{{cite news|last=Vorsino |first=Mary |url=http://archives.starbulletin.com/2003/12/21/news/story10.html |title=Steve Hirano obituary|newspaper=[[Honolulu Star-Bulletin]] |date=2003-12-21 |accessdate=2013-07-08}}</ref>
== Aftermath == Following the Hawaii accident of August 20, 1994, Tyke became symbolic of circus tragedies and a symbol for animal rights.<ref>{{cite news|last=Bernardo |first=Rosemarie |url=http://archives.starbulletin.com/2004/08/16/news/story2.html |title=Shots killing elephant echo across a decade |newspaper=Honolulu Star-Bulletin |date=2004-08-16 |accessdate=2013-07-08}}</ref> In the aftermath, lawsuits were filed against the City of Honolulu, the State of Hawaii, the circus, and Tyke's owner, John Cuneo, Jr. and his Hawthorn Corp. Honolulu lawyer William Fenton Sink sued Cuneo on behalf of numerous plaintiffs, including young children, who suffered psychological injuries after witnessing Tyke's killing. While the lawsuits were settled out of court, the details of the monetary decision was kept sealed from publication. In honor of Sink's work in the Tyke case, Animal Rights Hawaii renamed its "Order of the Innocent Award", The William Fenton Sink Award for Defense of Animals.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2004/Aug/20/ln/ln19a.html |title=Slain elephant left tenuous legacy in animal rights |last=Hoover |first=Will |newspaper=[[The Honolulu Advertiser]] |date=2004-08-20 |accessdate=2013-07-08}}</ref>
Allen Campbell's autopsy revealed that he died from severe internal injuries, including major skull and chest fractures. It was also determined Campbell had cocaine and alcohol in his system at the time of his death.<ref name=sahagun>{{cite news |author=Sahagun, Louis |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1994-10-11/news/mn-49101_1_captive-elephant |title=Elephants Pose Giant Dangers |newspaper=[[The Los Angeles Times]] |date=1994-10-11 |accessdate=2014-03-14}}</ref><ref name=wtae>{{cite web |title=Archived copy |last=Parsons |first=Jim |agency=WTAE, Team 4 |date=2002-11-21 |url=http://www.wtae.com/team4/1800419/detail.html |accessdate=2007-12-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724132848/http://www.wtae.com/team4/1800419/detail.html |archivedate=24 July 2011 |df= }} </ref> Officials at the [[Denver Zoo]] confirmed that there were complaints of animal abuse filed against Campbell during the late 1980s, when he operated an elephant and camel ride concession in the city.<ref name=wtae/>
The Tyke incident inspired legislation on local levels in Hawaii and abroad, while [[California]] Congressman [[Sam Farr]] introduced legislation ([http://commdocs.house.gov/committees/judiciary/hju65825.000/hju65825_0.HTM HR2323]) into the House of Representatives in 1999 and again in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.naiaonline.org/articles/article/congress-considers-ban-on-performing-elephants |title=Congress Considers Ban on Performing Elephants |last=Strand |first=Patti |publisher=[[National Animal Interest Alliance]] |date=2012-01-09 |accessdate=2013-07-08}}</ref>
== In popular culture == Experimental [[hardcore punk]]/[[powerviolence]] band [[Man Is the Bastard]] wrote the song "Tyke", about the elephant's escape and rebellion. The song was included on their 1995 album ''[[Thoughtless...]]''.<ref>''Man Is The Bastard – Thoughtless...'', web page on [https://www.discogs.com/it/Man-Is-The-Bastard-Thoughtless/master/92952 www.discogs.com] (accessed on March 23, 2016)</ref>
Christian [[thrash metal]] band [[Tourniquet (band)|Tourniquet]], known for its stance against animal abuse, wrote the song "86 Bullets" about Tyke for their 2012 album ''[[Antiseptic Bloodbath]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tourniquet.bandcamp.com/album/antiseptic-bloodbath |title=Antiseptic Bloodbath |website=[[Bandcamp.com]] |date=July 2012 |accessdate=2013-07-08}}</ref>
Author K.A. Monroe was inspired by the Tyke incident and published a popular independent children's book ''Tyke and the Elephant Angel''.<ref>http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/18278857-tyke-and-the-elephant-angel</ref>
Tyke is also seen on [[History (U.S. TV network)|The History Channel]] show ''[[Shockwave (TV Series)|Shockwave]]'', ''[[World's Most Amazing Videos]],''<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ztqZpx0loTk</ref> ''[[Banned from Television]]'' and ''[[Maximum Exposure]]''.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-CEFgITBpUA</ref>
The [[Hawaii Five-O (1968 TV series)|Hawaii Five-O]] [[Hawaii Five-0 (2010 TV series)|remake]] also mentions the Honolulu attack in [[Hawaii Five-0 (2010 TV series, season 6)#ep138|Season 6, Episode 20 ''Ka Haunaele (Rampage)'']].

{{Infobox U.S. legislation | name = War Crimes Act of 1996 | fullname = An Act To amend title 18, United States Code, to carry out the international obligations of the United States under the Geneva Conventions to provide criminal penalties for certain war crimes | acronym = | nickname = | enacted by = 104th | effective date = | public law url = | cite public law = {{USPL|104|192}} | cite statutes at large = {{USStat|110|2104}} | acts amended = | acts repealed = | title amended = 18 | sections created = {{USC|18|2441}}
renumbered from §2401 through the [[Economic Espionage Act of 1996]] §605(p)(1) | sections amended = | leghisturl = http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d104:HR03680:@@@S | introducedin = House | introducedbill = {{USBill|104|HR|3680}} | introducedby = [[Walter B. Jones, Jr.]] ([[Republican Party (United States)|R]]-[[North Carolina|NC]]) | introduceddate = June 19, 1996 | committees = [[United States House Committee on the Judiciary|House Judiciary]] | passedbody1 = House | passeddate1 = July 29, 1996 | passedvote1 = [[voice vote]] | passedbody2 = Senate | passeddate2 = August 2, 1996 | passedvote2 = [[unanimous consent]] | signedpresident = [[Bill Clinton]] | signeddate = August 21, 1996 | amendments = [[Military Commissions Act of 2006]] | SCOTUS cases = }} The '''War Crimes Act of 1996''' is a law that defines a [[war crime]] to include a "[[Geneva Conventions#Grave breaches|grave breach]] of the [[Geneva Conventions]]", specifically noting that "grave breach" should have the meaning defined in any convention (related to the [[laws of war]]) to which the [[United States]] is a party. The definition of "grave breach" in some of the Geneva Conventions have text that extend additional protections, but all the Conventions share the following text in common: "... committed against persons or property protected by the Convention: willful killing, [[torture]] or [[Cruel and unusual punishment|inhuman treatment]], including biological experiments, willfully causing great suffering or serious injury to body or health." The law applies if either the victim or the perpetrator is a national of the United States or a member of the [[U.S. Armed Forces]]. The penalty may be [[life imprisonment]] or [[death penalty|death]]. The death penalty is only invoked if the conduct resulted in the death of one or more victims. The act was passed with overwhelming majorities by the [[United States Congress]] and signed into law by [[President of the United States|President]] [[Bill Clinton]]. ==Legislative history== The law criminalized breaches of the Geneva Conventions so that the United States could prosecute war criminals, specifically [[North Vietnam]]ese soldiers who tortured U.S. military personnel during the [[Vietnam War]]. The [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] "fully support[ed] the purposes of the bill,"{{cite news | first = R. Jeffrey | last = Smith | authorlink = R. Jeffrey Smith | title = Detainee Abuse Charges Feared | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/07/27/AR2006072701908_pf.html | work = [[Washington Post]] | page = A1 | date = 2006-07-28 | accessdate = 2006-10-04}} recommending that it be expanded to include a longer list of war crimes. Because the United States generally followed the Conventions, the military recommended making breaches by U.S. military personnel war crimes as well "because doing so set a high standard for others to follow." The bill passed by [[unanimous consent]] in the Senate and by a [[voice vote]] in the House, showing that it was entirely uncontroversial at the time. Ten years later, the [[United States Supreme Court]] ruled in ''[[Hamdan v. Rumsfeld]]''{{ussc|548|05-184|2006}} that [[Geneva Conventions#Common Article 3|Common Article 3 of the Geneva Conventions]] applied to the [[War on Terrorism]], with the unstated implication that any [[enhanced interrogation|interrogation technique]] that violated Common Article 3 constituted war crimes.{{cite web | url = http://www.commondreams.org/views06/0630-27.htm | title = Did Bush Commit War Crimes? | accessdate = 2006-10-04 | last = Brooks | first = Rosa | authorlink = Rosa Brooks | date = 2006-06-30 | work = [[Los Angeles Times]] | quote = In other words, with the Hamdan decision, U.S. officials found to be responsible for subjecting war on terror detainees to torture, cruel treatment or other 'outrages upon personal dignity' could face prison or even the death penalty.}} The possibility that American officials and military personnel could be prosecuted for war crimes for committing the "outrages upon personal dignity, in particular humiliating and degrading treatment"{{cite web | url = http://www.unhchr.ch/html/menu3/b/91.htm | title = Geneva Convention relative to the Treatment of Prisoners of War | accessdate = 2006-10-04 | author = Diplomatic Conference for the Establishment of International Conventions for the Protection of Victims of War | date = 1949-08-12 | publisher = [[United Nations]] Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights | page = I, a. 3, 1(c) |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061001201518/http://www.unhchr.ch/html/menu3/b/91.htm |archivedate = 2006-10-01}} prohibited by the Conventions led to a series of proposals to make such actions legal in certain circumstances, which resulted in the [[Military Commissions Act of 2006]]. ==Potential application== [[White House]] officials were concerned that they and other U.S. officials could be prosecuted under the War Crimes Act for the U.S. treatment of detainees after the [[September 11 attacks]] for violations of the Geneva Conventions. In a January 2002 memorandum to the president, then-[[White House Counsel]] [[Alberto Gonzales]] authored a controversial memo that explored whether Common Article 3 of the Geneva Conventions applied to [[Al Qaeda]] and [[Taliban]] [[combatants]] captured during the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|war in Afghanistan]] and held in detention facilities around the world, including [[Camp X-Ray]] in [[Guantánamo Bay, Cuba|Guantanamo Bay]], [[Cuba]]. The memo made several arguments both for and against providing Common Article 3's protections to Al Qaeda and Taliban combatants. He concluded that Common Article 3 was outdated and ill-suited for dealing with captured Al Qaeda and Taliban combatants. He described as "quaint" the provisions that require providing captured Al Qaeda and Taliban combatants "commissary privileges, scrip, athletic uniforms, and scientific instruments". He also argued that existing military regulations and instructions from the President were more than adequate to ensure that the principles of the Geneva Conventions would be applied. He also argued that undefined language in the Geneva Conventions, such as "outrages upon personal dignity" and "inhuman treatment", could make officials and military leaders subject to the War Crimes Act of 1996 if mistreatment was discovered.Gonzales, Alberto. [http://msnbc.msn.com/id/4999148/site/newsweek/ Decision Re Application of the Geneva Convention on Prisoners of War to the Conflict with Al Qaeda and the Taliban], Memorandum for the President, January 25, 2002. (PDF file provided by MSNBC/Newsweek) The adoption of the [[Military Commissions Act of 2006]], defined in Section 6 of the act grave abuses of Common Article 3 to only include torture, cruel or inhumane treatment, [[murder]], [[mutilation]] or [[maiming]], intentionally causing serious bodily harm, [[rape]], [[sexual assault]] or abuse, and the [[hostage|taking of hostages]], thereby limiting the scope of the original law. ==See also== *[[Command responsibility]] *[[Nuremberg Trials]] *[[War crimes committed by the United States]] *[[Abu Ghraib torture and prisoner abuse]] *[[Human rights in the United States]] *[[The Prosecution of George W. Bush for Murder]] *[[The International Criminal Court and the 2003 invasion of Iraq]] *[[United States and the International Criminal Court]] *[[Vietnam War Crimes Working Group Files]] ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == *[http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/z?c104:H.R.3680: Federal Law 18 USC Sec. 2441] known as the "War Crimes Act" *[http://assembler.law.cornell.edu/uscode/18/2441.html US Code, Part I, Title 18, Chapter 118, section 2441] * Human Rights First; [http://www.humanrightsfirst.org/wp-content/uploads/pdf/07801-etn-leave-no-marks.pdf Leave No Marks: Enhanced Interrogation Techniques and the Risk of Criminality], August 2007 [[Category:1996 in law]] [[Category:United States federal defense and national security legislation]] [[Category:Laws of war]] [[Category:War crimes]] [[Category:Anti-torture laws]] [[Category:1996 in the United States]] [[Category:National laws incorporating the Geneva Conventions]]
